title: 109_hr3672
content: The Act titled "TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005" allows for the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 authorizes the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, despite the usual payment schedule. Additionally, the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program is extended through December 31, 2005, following the activities authorized for fiscal year 2005. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 allows advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program is extended through December 31, 2005, following the activities authorized for fiscal year 2005. Additional appropriations are made as necessary for this purpose. Section 403(a)(3)(H)(ii) of the Social Security Act is amended to change the deadline from September 30 to December 31. Section 403(b)(3)(C)(ii) is also amended to change the year from 2005 to 2006. Additionally, Section 409(a)(7) is amended to update the years mentioned from 2005 to 2006 and 2007. Extension of the National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority through December 31, 2005, with appropriations authorized for fiscal year 2005. Grants and payments may continue through the first. Grants and payments can be made until the first quarter of fiscal year 2006 at the same level as in fiscal year 2005. SEC. 3. Reimbursement of states for TANF benefits provided to assist families affected by Hurricane Katrina from other states. Beginning with the enactment of this Act until August 31, 2006, a State qualifies as needy if it has provided short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits to families affected by Hurricane Katrina in another State declared a disaster area. The Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act applies to families affected by Hurricane Katrina who have traveled to a State from another State due to the hurricane. The State must confirm that the family is not receiving cash benefits from any other State-funded program. Funding limitations apply to needy States under the Social Security Act. The payment to a needy State under the Social Security Act for families affected by Hurricane Katrina shall not exceed the total cash benefits provided, with no State match required for the payment. SEC. 4. AVAILABILITY OF ADDITIONAL TANF FUNDS FOR HURRICANE-DAMAGED STATES. Certain States like Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are eligible for loans under the Social Security Act until the end of fiscal year 2006. The total loan amount for these states cannot exceed 20 percent of their family assistance grant for that year. Additionally, these loans can be forgiven under certain circumstances. The States of Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are eligible for loans under the Social Security Act until the end of fiscal year 2006. The loans can be forgiven under certain circumstances, and penalties cannot be imposed for non-repayment or interest payment failures. SEC. 5 allows States or tribes to use unspent TANF funds to support needy families affected by Hurricane Katrina without fiscal year limitation. SEC. 6 states that work requirements and time limits under the TANF program are not triggered by families receiving temporary benefits due to the hurricane. SEC. 6 exempts families affected by Hurricane Katrina from work requirements and time limits under the TANF program if they receive short-term benefits to meet subsistence needs. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states (Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama) from Hurricane Katrina until the end of fiscal year 2006 if failure to comply was due to the hurricane or state's reasonable conduct in addressing victims' needs. SEC. 8. EMERGENCY DESIGNATION. Each amount in this Act (excluding section 2) is designated as an emergency requirement under section 402 of H. Con. Res. 95 (109th Congress).
